Situation1: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story:
I sat in the cramped break room, white coat draped over my chair, skimming the latest pharmacy newsletter. New drug approvals, updated guidelines—my mind raced to keep up. I knew I had to stay sharp; patients depended on my knowledge. Just as I highlighted a section on a promising new anticoagulant, my phone buzzed. It was Brother Ahmed, a long-time congregant. His message was brief but heavy: “Imam, can we meet soon? My family is falling apart. I need your guidance.” 

I stared at the screen, feeling the weight of his trust. As an imam, I was expected to be present, to listen, to offer comfort and wisdom. But as a pharmacist, I was expected to be current, to never let my expertise slip. Both roles demanded my full attention, both were urgent in their own way. My heart pounded as I looked between the newsletter and my phone, torn by the impossible choice between professional responsibility and spiritual duty.
